captions.text: I found the secret to life

and it started
with a stress-induced bald spot.

At the age of 31 I found myself in a rut,
personally and professionally.

The final straw was waking up 
one morning, to discover

a bald spot the size of a quarter
that appeared overnight.

I had to do something 
and my birthday was coming up,

so I decided to give myself 
the ultimate birthday gift: a fresh start.

I put my resignation letter into cupcakes 
and pass them out at the office.
(Laughter)

I left the guy I thought I was going 
to marry, my city and my friends,

I moved to Chicago from New York, 
heartbroken and ready to start over.

I landed a dream job, 
I found a great apartment.
Life was really starting to turn around.

But about a month into this new life,
I realized something was missing.
I didn't have any friends.

So I decided to make a new friend 
every single day, for a year.

I waited till as long as possible 
to tell people about the project,

because I wanted the encounters 
to be authentic.
I had three simple rules:

it had to be 
a significant social exchange,
I had to feel a connection,

and I couldn't go home 
until I made a friend.

It took anywhere from 30 minutes 
to 12 hours to make a friend

and this was all 
while I had a full time job.
I hadn't set out to make anything,

I wasn't trying to get famous 
through a gimmick.
I truly needed friends.

But once someone agreed 
to be my friend for the day,
I documented the experience.

I photographed them, 
and that night I would go home

and write a two-hundred word narrative 
about the encounter.

I asked all of them 
one consistent question, which is,
"Why are you here?"

Every morning I woke up 
to this huge weight on my shoulder,

wondering how I was going 
to meet someone that day.

And when I walked out my door
I was open to connecting.
Believe it or not, about 80% of the time

I was not the person 
who initiated conversation.
I let the project dictate my life

and ironically, it was so freeing 
not to have control.
I had permission to follow adventure.

Like staying out really late 
on a work night,

or inviting a convicted murderer, 
just days out of jail,
to join me and tell me his story.

Or getting a ride from a stranger 
to an underground dinner party,
where I knew no one.

I met artists, business men, musicians, 
an actor en-route to Los Angeles,
Mike Mills from R.E.M, a suicidal student,

a drunk paramedic, 
a drag queen who loves Thanksgiving,
a roller Derby girl named Badgy Sandwitch,
(Laughter)
a publisher of porn, a homeless man,
the list goes on.
I'm an outgoing person

but having to connect with a new person,
every single day for a year,
was the hardest thing I've ever done.

It was daunting to think 
about the scope of the project.

So I just focused 
on what I had to do that day,
meet one person.

And because I knew 
people were going to say,

"Who'd you meet yesterday?"
I had to keep going.
And I couldn't fake it either.

Because everyday required another person 
to help me complete my mission.

This project rode the line 
between emotional need and art.

I was meeting all of these people, 
but really I was getting to know myself.

And through this project, I learned 
how important authentic connection is,
and how badly we all crave it.

I would get calls 
from people in the project
who'd met another one of my friends,
and it would go something like this,
"Hey Maria! It's your May 23rd,"

-- they identified 
with the date I met them--,
"Oh, hey May 23rd. How are you doing?"

"Good, good. I was at a bridal shower 
and I met your January 6th."
(Laughter)

They felt a part of something,
and little did I know

that would be a key revelation 
in future projects.

Now the first 15 seconds are definitely 
the hardest moments
when it comes to meeting a new person.
Affinity groups are great because you know

you have at least one thing in common 
with the people there.

Props are also really good at providing 
an entry point for conversation.
I once brought a goldfish out with me.

I sat it on the bar 
and I ordered a scotch,
and that goldfish was the best wingman.
(Laughter)

Everyone there...
people could not help themselves,
they had to come up and talk to me.

I know one guy that likes 
to bring pinatas on airplanes,
because it causes conversations.

I think we're just all looking 
for an excuse to connect.
Or perhaps it's permission.

But connection takes being open, 
and being open is scary,

because you have to go out 
of your comfort zone
and you have to trust strangers.
It's work that might not pay off.

But being open has led to some 
of the most profound moments in my life.

I was heading down to Austin, 
I was on a flight,
and I sat next to a middle aged woman,

and she was reading a book,
"How to start a museum."
Intrigued, I asked her about the book,

and we ended up 
talking most of the flight.
Peggy became my November 8th.

A few weeks later 
I got an e-mail from Peggy,
and she told me about her return flight.

She was sitting next to a woman, 
they did not talk the whole time,
and then she was waiting for her bags

and she found herself 
standing next to the same woman.

Peggy, remembering our encounter, 
went up to the woman,
and told her about the project.

She then told the woman 
about the one question I asked her,
which is, "Why are you here?"

The woman, without hesitating, 
blurted out,

"I'm here for my sister. 
She has breast cancer."

Well, Peggy's sister
is a survivor of breast cancer.

When they made this connection,
they hugged.

This was the first time that I realized 
the ripple effect of the project.

That I was affecting people 
I did not even know.

I was at a Starbucks,
and a guy named Brett,
my January 20th, started talking to me.
He was desperate for a friend.

He had just gotten back from Iraq, 
he was honorably discharged,
the military was his life.

He was suffering from stress, 
guilt and an identity crisis.

At one point, he went 
into the Starbucks bathroom
to drink a fifth of vodka,
so he can muster the courage to tell me,

how he accidentally killed 
a civilian family in Falusia.

I spent a couple of hours 
just listening to Brett,

as he told 
one horrific story after another.
And with each story, I could tell

that he was getting lighter 
and I was getting heavier

with this emotional baggage 
he'd been carrying around.
I never saw Brett again,

but I know I gave him the best gift 
I could have given him at that moment,
someone to listen.

And listening is active 
and it's at the core of friendship.

Because I knew I had to go home 
every night
and write a story about each encounter,

I paid really close attention 
to what was said.

I wish I could say
I still listen as intently,

but I find ever present technology 
and the chaos of life
makes it hard to listen to each other.

I introduced my August 9th 
to my October 20th

and they got married 
and they now live in Paris.
(Laughter)

So you don't have to know someone well
to have a profound impact on them.

We all have the power to change 
the course of each others' lives.

At the end of the year 
I brought everyone together,

for a gallery show of the stories
and so they can meet each other.

And when the project ended,
I found myself fundamentally transformed.
Somewhere along the way I lost my fear.
I developed a stronger sense of self,

and a curiosity for people and adventure 
that I did not have before.
So, why is connecting so important?

A Harvard grant study 
followed a group of people for 75 years

in order to unearth the secrets 
to a happy and purposeful life.

And the study found strong relationships 
to be far and away

the biggest predictor 
of life satisfaction.

In fact, the study's 
most important finding

is that the only thing 
that matters in life is relationships.

And as time goes on, relationships 
or connections become more important.

The study found strong support 
for growing body of research

that has linked social ties 
with longevity,

lower stress levels 
and improved over all well being.

When we connect with each other, 
that is when we are the most alive.
The "Friend a day" project

caused me to do things 
I've never would have done otherwise.
I was out of my comfort zone everyday,

and that's when I really got 
to know who I was.
To know others is to know yourself.
Think about it.

If you were on a deserted island 
with one other person,

you'd only know yourself 
in relation to that one person.

But now imagine you're on an island 
with four hundred people.
You now have four hundred data points.

But we, my friends, are on a planet 
of seven billion people.

That is seven billion different ways 
to get to know ourselves.

In a world that is becoming 
more virtual everyday,

it's more important than ever 
to experience authentic connections.

So I challenge all of you 
to look for opportunities,

and embrace the risk 
of bringing new people into your life.

You will not only know yourself better, 
but you'll feel more fulfilled.
You may even live longer.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Lessons learned from making a new friend every day for a year: Maria Scileppi at TEDxVeniceBeach
